title: If laws of physics exist, does it mean free will doesn't exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: That is a very good question and one that physicists, philosophers, and theologians have discussed since Newton (and probably before). In Newtonian mechanics each event causes the next one and so forth. With the discovery of atoms however we realized the large objects are actually made up of small parts that do NOT follow these laws. When you average together the behavior of enough atoms you get the expected result plus or minus a small amount of uncertainty. Einstein greatly improved our understanding of this with is work on the Photoelectric Effect for which he won a Nobel Prize. (Most people think he won a Nobel Prize for Relativity, but that’s incorrect.) Einstein’s work showed that individually atoms act like dice, BUT Einstein vehemently opposed the idea that “God plays with dice.” I personally believe that humans have souls, but even without that we must consider the complex chemistry of the brain and how decisions are made. The brain uses many complex chemical reactions and combines them together, BUT it does NOT average them. If you have a large piece of aluminum and hit it with something, you can predict with nearly infinite certainty what the block as whole will do. You can predict what each atom at the point of collision is most likely to do, but not what it will actually do. Human decisions are made from chemicals in the brain that act like those atoms at the collision point on the aluminum, not like the whole block. Your statement about atoms indicates a common misconception. The movement of atoms is actually only probabilistic — they will probably go in a particular direction but they are NOT Newtonian objects. We can not say that they “choose” which way to go — but they are not deterministic the way we often think they are. Many students incorrectly believe that this uncertainty in the motion of atoms is the result of an inability to measure the atoms rather than a property of the atoms themselves, but this is incorrect. It is true that measuring devices have limits, but the atoms themselves have limits. We can say that they themselves “do not know” their own speed and position “exactly” and this is an actual, physical property of atoms. This is as much a “LAW” as f=ma and the Newtonian “laws” that supposedly make the future “predetermined.” So yes, in short, we do have “free will.”

An interesting problem which dates back to the idea of the “clockwork universe” which followed Newton’s theories. The thinking goes that if the universe is truly deterministic and started from a particular point then surely all it’s future actions, including those of any people, were pre-determined. At best, we’d just have an illusion of free will, but in reality our decisions are pre-determined. At the time of Newton this didn’t cause to much of a controversy as, to the religious minded (or at least those from Abrahamic faiths), the essence of the person was not determined by mere physical phenomenon. Freewill was god-given and part of their spirit and hence not part of the corporeal world. It was therefore not governed by physical laws. However, as the influence of religion faded then this issue came back to haunt, especially those who didn’t believe in a deity. With the emergence of Quantum Mechanics, physicists realised that in a very fundamental way the universe is not deterministic. It is, really, based on probability and uncertainty woven into the whole structure. In addition, chaos theory tells us that the outcome of even the simplest non-linear systems can produce wildly unpredictable outcomes unless we know the starting conditions of a system absolutely perfectly (which QM tells us we can’t). QM would therefore appear to get us out of this “clockwork universe” catch and open a gap for free will to emerge. However, even this doesn’t appear quite true. It just allows for a probabilistic outcome of a decision, not the controlled one that true free will would appear to require. There is, perhaps, a bit of evidence that much of our free-will is a really an illusion. Experiments have demonstrated that we often appear to make decisions. Neuroscientists can now observe behaviour in the brain at the time of decision making and it has become clear that some are made before we become consciously aware of a phenomenon. It is, in effect, our sub-conscious activities making the decision for us. We see this in sports of course - no tennis player could hit a ball correctly if he/she had to think consciously about exactly where the ball was going to be. However, there’s also evidence that our subconscious also makes value judgements. There is plenty of experimental evidence our reaction to, say, race, is often not conscious. Indeed what the conscious mind often appears to do is censor our unconscious reactions. On another point, Roger Penrose in his book The Emperor’s New Mind claims that the behaviour of the brain (and hence consciousness) cannot be modelled mathematically, including as that of a quantum mechanical system as we currently know it. He claims to have proved that there is no way that consciousness can emerge from such a system. He has further elaborated this by claiming that there is an enormous gap between the quantum (non-deterministic) word and that of the classical (deterministic) world. His position is that there is a massive gap in our physical explanation of the world when something transitions from this quantum state to the classical one (the same sort of space occupied by Schrodinger’s cat) and that it is in this new, unexplained, non-computational part of physics wherein will lie the solution to the enigma of consciousness and, by implication, free will. Naturally Penrose’s position is highly controversial, especially in the area of Artificial Intelligence and the physics is speculative indeed (although he’s “only” claiming a gap).

The answer is no. I argue that the laws of science preclude a deterministic or wholly deterministic universe. One of the reasons for this is that emergent properties break the cause effect chains. For example, a car designer can design a car to perform on asphalt roads and can predict the measurable specifications desired: top speed, gas mileage, etc. But an emergent property of roads and cars is … traffic. The parameters used to establish the abilities of cars do not predict the existence of traffic. There are many phenomena that aren’t seemingly deterministic, is another reason: radioactive decay rates are probabilistic and quantum phenomena are far from deterministic. I also use the example of a large poker tournament, say the word Series of Poker. Is anyone going to argue that the hands being played are all determined by physical causes. I saw one of the world’s best players throw away a winning hand and later he stated that he didn’t see the flush he had. What determined that result? Decision after decision is made in such a tournament, often on whims, guesses, personal theories, mistakes, and probabilities wrongly calculated. Coming up with a deterministic explanation for all of the choices made in such a set of circumstances seems impossible. The issue I have with most arguments is that free will advocates insist upon it being conscious free will. If we make a decision subconsciously, it is claimed that this is some sort of robotic, deterministic, controlled decision. Now that we know that our subconscious minds use the exact same brain structures as our conscious minds use, I don’t see how this is defensible.

I see the obsession over the existence over free will itself to be quite absurd. Not absurd as in Camus’ existentialist absurdism (which in itself I find quite absurd), but more so that such questions are completely devoid of subjectivity, of nuance, of the sheer human idiocy, or our inherent nature to be utter imbeciles, which are what lend us our meaning of life. Objectively, in a fashion in which puts a sole human alone on a moon kind of objectivism, perhaps Camus’ crowd are right, there is no inherent purpose in life, no objective direction towards which we are headed, but this approach is idiotic like trying to discern and break head figuring out the meaning of a lemon on a kitchen counter. Perhaps Camus’ grandmother should have tapped his head and fed him chilled glass of lemon juice. Our meaning in life, our purpose comes from the subjectivity we share with life. Our perceptions, our upbringing, all individually combine to form our world view, our likes and dislikes, which dictates then the set of choices we are biased towards. Free will is an idiotic conception, because it devoids the very aspect of life that contextualizes our freedom, and then asks we are free or not when it comes to making choices. “We're all made of atoms, we all have to obey the same rule too, we can't move freely, or otherwise, we break the law.” You’re making an error. You’re assuming we are the summation of all our atoms. We are not. Read Where You Cannot Generalize from Knowledge of Parts (continuation of the Minority Rule)

This is a matter of philosophy. One could argue that free will does not exist. Everything in our universe can be explained by physics. We are not capable of predicting the future due to a lack of scientific theory or a lack of computational power. In theory, if we had a super computer 10^9999999 times more powerful than anything that exists today AND we developed the physics and mathematics to explain everything that occurs in our world, we could predict the state of the universe at some future time. In other words, we could predict where are the particles will be a few seconds from now, where the energy has transferred to, etc etc… Our brains and bodies are governed by the laws of physics just like every other system in the universe. What you believe is “free will” is actually a complex combination of electric signals and chemical reactions. Since our super computer is capable of predicting these processes, our computer is capable of predicting what choices you will make in the future. If our super computer can determine the actions you take in the future, did you really have any choice?

It depends on what domain or “level of description” and the definition of freewill you are using. At the level of description of psychology and sociology, and in our everyday lives, you can talk about making “choices” and “decisions”. In fact, you have to, otherwise all discussion in psychology and sociology, and all human verbal interaction, grinds to a halt. But, at the level of classical physics, and chemistry and biology, there is just determinism. Even at the quantum level, some interpretations of quantum physics are deterministic and, in all interpretations of quantum physics, Schroedingers equation - which describes the evolution of the wave function - is deterministic. But I would avoid the use of the word “freewill”. Because those “choices” and “decisions” are neither “free” nor “willed”. Unless of course you do mean that it is “free” and “willed”, but then you are wrong because that variety of freewill - called contracausal freewill - does not exist. Some re-define freewill to mean something that is neither “free” nor “willed” - called compatibilist freewill - in which case, my only response is “what did you do that for?”.

I can offer only my personal opinion. Freewill is a choice, a purely intellectual phenomenon governed by how and why we respond to events. Those events will - must - influence our reactions and may present few choices. All choices are determined by the event, the character of the person, the degree of self-interest in his character, and his emotional state of mind. This makes it virtually impossible for any person to know for certain what he/she might do in any given circumstances. Instant reaction is automatic, allowing time only for built-in controls to act, almost without conscious thought. That action is pre-determined. When time is available, even if only a few seconds, conscious thought allows choices. Again, actions will reflect an individual's make-up. As these reactions are variable they can be determined by the individual. Even though they amount to little real choice - mayhap no choice! - the reaction is one of freewill.

Let’s quickly consider the divide separating physical laws and human will. Because of the laws of physics, you can’t suddenly decide to inhale sulfur tetrafluoride and exhale helium. You decided to write this question of your own free will Because of the laws of physics, you can’t jump up and propel yourself into orbit. You either decided to read this silly answer or you decided to ignore it of your own free will. Because of the laws of physics, you can’t decide to blink your eyes and suddenly observe everything in infrared radiation instead of visible You will go for a walk today or not, depending on your mood. Because of the laws of physics, you cannot avoid having innumerable solar neutrinos move through your body every second. Natural laws govern much of what we do, but not everything.

People keep asking if this or that precludes or demands free will but they refuse to define free will sufficiently to make the argument answerable. What do you mean by free will? It is usually an ill-posed question. If you mean, given a choice, can you make it, the answer is clearly yes, and this has nothing to do with determinism. If determinism is at play, how can you possibly test your hypothesis? We can’t go back in time and collect evidence that your choice would be different given exactly the same conditions. And, if we did do that and you did choose different at least once, why? If the conditions were exactly the same and you chose differently, isn’t your method of choice randomness? How is randomness free will? Randomness is a lack of choosing, like rolling the dice and letting “fate” decide. So, you either make decisions based on circumstances, knowledge, and logic or you are governed by randomness. Whether the universe is deterministic or not isn’t relevant to the question of choice, and if it isn’t a choice, how is it free will? So, what is free will?

The origin and working of what one usually calls “free will” is not yet sufficiently well understood at the level of neurobiology. So, at present, there does not seem to exist a scientifically satisfactory (or fruitful) answer to the question. Preliminary indications are that human willing might not be a consciously free act, whether the laws of physics are deterministic or probabilistic in origin.

Everything depends on what you mean by “free will” There are three positions. One is determinism which is what you are suggesting. A second denies universal determinism and so affirms free will that is trans causal. A third is what is called compatibilism which contends that freedom and causal determinism are compatible. For this last group the proper contrast is not with causal determinism but with constraint. If I am tied to the chair I am not free to move around but if I am not I am free. If I am under a psychological compulsion to steal then I am not free.

The existence of ‘free will’ as it is popularly conceived requires two things to exist or occur: Physical events that are not caused by other physical events, but are caused by:Mental intentions that are not physical states.We have some reason to think that there might be events matching description 1. But we have no reason to think there is anything matching description 2. So while it is possible that some events happen for ‘no reason’ — though all the ones we currently know anything about occur at the sub-atomic level and are utterly trivial — nobody’s succeeded in explaining how they could possibly hook up with human desires and motivations.

Depends on how you define “free will”. If it just means that your will is not predetermined, then yes, this follows. If the laws of nature are deterministic then everything in the universe is predetermined, including your will. But is that definition of free will really interesting? Would it really be better is what you want is partially determined by chance? Does that really make you any more free? I think most people who wants free will to exist, is not just that it should not be predetermined, but they do not want it to be governed by any rules at all, deterministic or not. They want to desire themselves what they want. This is of course circular and impossible. So, free will cannot exist, ever.

Free will is a social belief about moral responsibility for one’s actions. It is usually applied as a punitive concept to discipline those who violate social conventions and has nothing to do with physics. In practice, in Western and Eastern societies, nonconformists are punished by blaming the violator for choosing a course of action that contravened group consensus. It is bound up with religious and legal precepts but has doubtful applicability outside the social sphere .

response.answer_text: To test whether something exists scientifically, all you need to do is tie the concept to evidence. Your concept of atoms are tied to the evidence of chemistry, the periodic table, and the observations from various experiments. What is your concept of free will tied to? If it is tied to the experience of free will, then it must exist, unless you somehow have means to deny the experience. I feel a choice. This feeling isn’t going away based on how I think of the feeling, because it’s the very thing I’m thinking about. If it is tied to a concept or a theory or a book or something that isn’t tied to anything physical, then there is a chance whatever you are talking about is imaginary. That doesn’t mean it doesn’t make sense, or isn’t interesting, or isn’t useful. It just means it isn’t real, in a physical sense, or that it hasn’t been confirmed as real for all practical purposes.

We don’t have to invoke the laws of physics or the universe to think through the simple logic regarding the idea of free will; free will just means we are free to make choices based on our preferences rather than coercion from outside. But here’s the catch: no one ever chose to have the preferences they happen to have, which moots the whole issue of free will, doesn’t it.

Free will is a contradiction in terms. It’s certainly not compatible in a universe with our type of physics. But it’s not compatible with any universe we can imagine. Even ones with supernatural souls, sprits, time-trave and flying unicorns. No one has yet described how this thing “a free will decision” actually comes into the universe. If a decision caused by prior events, it is not free. If a decision is not caused by prior events, it’s not free or willed.

Einstein quoting Schopenhauer: “I man can do what he wills to do, but he cannot determine what he wills.” That some things are uncertain at the Planck level until they occur, would seem to discredit predestination and determinism, but perhaps even uncertainty is uncertain.

Determinism is a prerequisite for free will, not an objection against it. If your actions can't be said to be determined by your prior beliefs/opinions/attitudes then they can't be described as your actions. They become involuntary spasms.

Free will results largely from the biological nature of the brain and the psychology of people, not from the laws physics. Physics does play a big role but personal differences between individuals are often largely a matter of biology and psychology and not of the physics of attitudes.

You will probably want to re-examine each of your premises. The ‘Laws of Physics’ govern nothing. They are expressions of the ways the universe functions. Period.The ‘Laws of Physics’ are not deterministic. They are probabilistic at the quantum level.

The laws aren’t ‘deterministic’. Revisit your understanding of Heisenberg’s work. That’s why Einstein made his famous wry observation - God does not play dice with the universe. But as we now know, Heisenberg was right and Einstein was wrong.

The known laws of physics are deterministic, or deterministic plus random. If all the laws of physics were known then free will could not exist. But not all of the laws of physics are known. There could be additional laws that empower mind or consciousness that we have not yet discovered. So the question is open.

Only if free will means our actions are undetermined, which would mean if we had that sort of free will we would be unable to function or survive. The majority of modern philosophers do not define free will that way.

Congratulations. You’re on you way to meeting Laplace’s Demon. Laplace's demon - Wikipedia However, modern understanding of physics includes aspects that are indeterminate. In other words, your question is flawed; the laws of physics are not all deterministic.

The laws of physics appear to be deterministic only at a superficial level. Since the early 20th century, it has been evident that the laws of physics are probabilistic. To understand physics requires a knowledge of maths and probability.
Well, the existence of free will is an obvious truth to all sentient humans. Therefore, the laws of physics cannot be deterministic.

The laws of physics determine only the effects for given causes, but they do not determine the causes. Free will operates by generating new causes, starting new causal chains of events in the hope of more desirable consequences.
This is an example of looking through the wrong end of our optical tools. You say our laws govern the universe,right? I say our laws do not govern the universe.
